awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Fundamental Investigation of Thin-Film Evaporation Using Crystalline Porous Inverse Opals
awd_abstract_narration:
Dissipating extreme heat through phase change processes (e.g. evaporation) is a daunting challenge for various applications ranging from modern electronic devices to power plant cooling. For this purpose, nanoscale structures have drawn significant interest due to their large surface area and ability to deliver working fluid to evaporating surfaces. However, to date it has been challenging to identify the role of the nanostructures in phase change processes owing to their complex structures. To address this problem, this CAREER project will employ extremely regular porous media to investigate thin-film evaporation physics. The structural regularity of such porous media will allow new relationships to be developed between the form of the material and the evaporation heat transfer. The research outcomes from this project will be integrated into educational and outreach activities to promote public interest in thermal transport phenomena and train the next generation of researchers. The integrated educational and outreach plan will be addressed through new sensory learning educational tools, research and mentoring programs, and a new graduate course on nanoscale phase change heat transfer topics. 

The scientific objective of this CAREER project is to find new discoveries in structure-related evaporation phase change physics utilizing new classes of well-ordered porous media. The specific tasks of this project include (1) demonstrating hydrophilic inverse opals with desired transport properties; (2) studying local thin-film evaporation at the pore-level (with the aim of understanding the role of the spherical concave shape of such pores on thin-film evaporation); and (3) examining heat transfer performance in the devices. The tasks can be accomplished by studying the self-assembly and metallization of the opal template with surface engineering, multiscale computational models, and high-fidelity measurements to validate understanding of evaporation performance. The new discoveries about the transport physics through porous media will provide a big step forward for the design of next-generation thermal management devices such as microfluidic channels, flexible coolers, and heat pipes that leverage emerging porous materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Managing heat in modern technology, from cooling electronic devices to power plant systems, is a critical challenge. As devices get smaller and more powerful, removing excess heat efficiently is increasingly difficult. This project focused on improving how heat is managed by studying innovative materials that can enhance cooling through a process called phase change—where liquids evaporate to absorb and dissipate heat. Specifically, the research explored how nanostructured and crystalline porous materials can be used to make phase change heat transfer more efficient. Nanomaterials, with their tiny structures, are promising for this purpose because they have large surface areas that can interact with fluids. However, most nanomaterials have random structures, making it hard to understand how they affect the cooling process. To address this, the project used carefully designed crystalline porous materials—materials with highly regular and uniform structures—to uncover how their shape and structure improve heat transfer during evaporation.

The main goal of this project was to improve the understanding of how structured materials can enhance heat management, particularly by making the evaporation process more efficient. The project specifically focused on: (1) Creating Crystalline Copper Materials - These materials, known as inverse opals, have a regular, highly organized pore structure that allows scientists to better study how they interact with fluids during evaporation. (2) Studying Thin-Film Evaporation - The research explored how the shape of these pores, which are spherical and concave, affects the way fluids evaporate on their surface. The idea was that the combination of unique shapes and surface chemistry could increase the surface evaporation. (3) Visualization of Phase Change Phenomena – The research also explored how visualization data can be autonomously analyzed using advanced computer vision and machine learning techniques to gain deeper insights into phase change phenomena.

The project not only advanced research in heat management but also aimed to inspire and engage students through a range of educational activities: (1) Sensory Learning Tools - The team developed interactive tools to teach younger students (K-12) about heat transfer, using creative methods such as artistic images to make the science more accessible and fun. (2) Mentoring Undergraduate Students - Undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds were given hands-on research opportunities, helping them gain valuable experience in this cutting-edge field. (3) Graduate Course Development - A new graduate-level course was created to teach students about nanoscale heat transfer and how new materials can improve cooling in modern technology.

By pushing the boundaries of how we understand and control heat transfer, this project has opened new possibilities for creating more efficient and reliable cooling systems across a wide range of applications. The research has the potential to significantly impact industries where effective heat management is essential, such as electronics and energy. Building on the success of this work, the PI has also established valuable collaborations with industrial partners, contributing to advancements in heat pipe design, microfluidic cooling systems, and energy storage technologies. These partnerships help translate the research findings into real-world applications, driving innovation in thermal management solutions.
